title: No. 3 LSU grinds out win over No. 10 Auburn to set up heavyweight showdown with Alabama
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: USA TODAY Sports' Paul Myerberg provides his opinion of the top three programs in the history of college football. USA TODAY

It wasn't always pretty, but No. 3 LSU ground out a 23-20 defeat of No. 10 Auburn in the annual "Tiger Bowl" on Saturday at Louisiana State's Tiger Stadium.

LSU put up a season low in points, thanks in part to a strong performance from Auburn's defense, but quarterback Joe Burrow and running back Clyde Edwards-Helaire provided enough offense in the second half to secure the victory.

The victory sets up a massive showdown with No. 1 Alabama at Bryant-Denny Stadium in two weeks that will likely determine the winner of the SEC West. The Crimson Tide play Arkansas later Saturday.

LSU Tigers quarterback Joe Burrow (9) celebrates with running back Clyde Edwards-Helaire after a touchdown run against the Auburn Tigers during the third quarter at Tiger Stadium. (Photo: Derick E. Hingle, USA TODAY Sports)

Auburn scored a field goal on its first possession of the second half to break a 10-10 tie that was set up by a 70-yard run by D.J. Williams. He nearly scored but stepped out of bounds at the LSU 9-yard line, and LSU was able to hold Auburn to the field goal.

LSU then drove down the field but turned the ball over on downs when Auburn stopped wide receiver Ja'Marr Chase on fourth down.

TOO GOOD: Big-time players have Ohio State looking like the No. 1 team

SILVER LINING: The one good thing for Oklahoma in loss to Kansas State

Auburn proceeded to go three-and-out, and though it picked off Burrow on LSU's subsequent possession it went three-and-out again.

LSU finally jumped into the lead again, 16-13, at 4:58 of the third quarter on Edwards-Helaire's touchdown run. After yet another Auburn three-and-out, LSU pushed its lead to 23-13 on Burrow's 7-yard touchdown run.

On LSU's side, Burrow, a favorite for the Heisman Trophy, had another strong game going 32-for-42 for 321 yards with a passing and running touchdown. Edwards-Helaire managed 137 yards on 25 carries to go with his one touchdown.

Freshman QB Bo Nix had a brutal game for Auburn. He finished just 15-for-35 for 157 yards with an interception and a late touchdown pass that cut the deficit to three.

Overall, LSU outgained Auburn 508-287.
description: LSU set a season low for scoring but it still beat Auburn 23-20 in a battle of Tigers that sets up a massive showdown with No. 1 Alabama in two weeks.
